I can't think of any that you haven't already done, so I'd keep up those. I liked the painting and wine one w/Collis but I couldn't make it.
Q22: Based on identity, or interest. Social sciences social, or idk. I think if we used Common Ground for more social events (dances) that'd be great. Quality music is lacking on this campus. DASA LLC formal was EPIC, at McLaughlin. Literally that was a scene. We need great DJs, thankfully the 19s back us up. At other Ivies they host parties in their student center, I think more of those would be great bc frat/ponging is kind of dull. I love dancing and lit music. I think that's where Greek life succeeds in doing, and alt social spaces should work on. Of course, we do have Cutter and LALACS parties, which are both great. I'm not sure if Bar Hop has dancing; I often can't go because it's in the middle of the week. So it would be great if Collis hosted one or two of these a term on a Friday or Saturday.

Q20: They take some advantage of these events
They don't take much advantage of these events
Q21: I really enjoy when there are free movies, concerts or theater performances at the Hop, so I'd love to see opportunities like that expanded. Having dance parties/formals outside of the Greek system would also be cool. In my opinion, Dartmouth should give more funding and support to the Living Learning Communities whose events have good attendance, and spend less funds on House Community events that people do not attend. The one event I attended at my House was supposed to be a major advising session. They had ordered about 15 Dominos pizzas. I was the only person who showed up. That's just wasteful. I think the House communities are trying really hard and I appreciate the effort, but I really don't think any of the upperclassmen students identify with their House communities and so I really don't think House events are a good way to try to attract students to alternative social spaces. The best events are those that attract people who are likely to attend Greek events -- for example, I've had friends who normally would go out but will instead go see a free movie at the Hop or go blacklight mini golfing, because those are the most widely-appealing alternative events. By contrast, in my experience very few people ever attend the craft-based events.
Q22: First, I would empower female dominated social spaces to host events; while not "alternative," such events would have a notably different vibe from the parties hosted in frats, which unfortunately sometimes lend themselves to sexism. Personally, I have found a really great community through my LLC, the Thought Project, and I think Dartmouth should continue to support its LLCs, which empower students to self-select into communities they care about (unlike the House system, which arbitrarily sorts students into random groups not based on interest and thus less likely to inspire commitment and engagement). In my experience, students are more likely to interact socially with other members of their LLCs than with their House communities, so I'd love to see Dartmouth expand the LLC model. I think the best thing Collis can do is offer events that are novel, exciting, and free, that attract people away from the frats for a night. Some of my favorite events have been blacklight minigolf/lazer tag, free movies, and spa nights, and I think these are the events that are so different from anything you could find in frats that they attract even affiliated students.

Q22: I think that "alternative social spaces," while providing great additional programming opportunities for students do not provide a perfect (or even close to perfect) substitute for Greek life on campus. The reality is that any event sponsored by organizations like CGB or LLCs, etc. have to limit alcohol to those 21+, and those spaces do not fill the same role as Greek spaces do on campus (for better or for worse.) If anything, I think looking at how to make Greek spaces host more "alternative" events is a good place to begin changing culture--for example, trivia or game night or karaoke in the first floor of a frat.

Q22: I would start an alternative option to the Greek community that is just called like "social life at Dartmouth", where you can opt into it Freshman year, and there will be co-ed spaces of ~50 people, each of which will inhabit a physical house on campus (maybe if other frats get derecognized, otherwise dorm areas). They will have library/study spaces, and spaces for pong and parties. This will stop the toxic masculinity on our campus, and hopefully most students will do this eventually in place of the Greek system (you can't be part of both). For this to work, the school will need to be committed to invest $$ into it in a smart fashion. Maybe turn this to the Dartmouth Consulting Group? Make it a student challenge with an amazing prize? Not sure exactly, but something radical needs to happen for alternative social spaces/unproblematic social spaces to happen.

Q21: Student run/driven/advertised. No one wants to go to an event facilitated by admins. They must come from a student community. Only caveat is house profs, who do a fairly good job with natural community building.
Q22: Start by supporting the groups/parts of campus that already succeed in inclusive, safe, diverse spaces as an alternative to greek life. For instance: the DOC already is a co-ed, education/leadership based, cross-class, student run, low-risk community that is achieving the goals of the college. Help them succeed more. The ultimate frisbee community is also a co-ed, low-risk, fun, inclusive, student run community that is very successful. Another: the engineering school is a fairly tight knit, co-ed, low-risk community that actually takes care of its members. Another: the dartmouth sustainability office fosters a really tight knit, co-ed community. Reinvest in the groups that are already creating successful alternatives to greek life. Give the DOC a house/plant to be run by students as a safe alternative to greek life. Give the frisbee program a house to do the same. Communities exist already that provide great alternatives to greek life AND are also student run. Start by supporting them. No matter what– there will be no good alternative to greek life that is not student run. Students should be trusted to run their own communities.
